verses.text: The plans of the heart belong to a person, but the answer of the tongue comes from the LORD.
verses.comment: This verse highlights human freedom balanced with God’s sovereignty. Our intentions matter, but God ultimately directs outcomes, showing the interplay of free will and divine providence. See Psalm 37:5.

verses.text: All the ways of a person are pure in his own eyes, but the LORD weighs the spirit.
verses.comment: What seems righteous to us may be flawed; God judges the heart. Spiritual self-examination is vital, as commended in Psalm 139:23.

verses.text: Commit your works to the LORD, and your plans will be established.
verses.comment: Entrusting God with our work is a spiritual act of surrender, echoing promises in Proverbs 3:5–6 about divine guidance for those who trust.

verses.text: The LORD has made everything for its purpose, even the wicked for the day of disaster.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty extends to all, including those who oppose Him, a theme deepened in Romans 9:17–18 concerning divine judgment and mercy.

verses.text: Everyone who is arrogant in heart is detestable to the LORD; be assured, he will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: Pride severs us from God’s favor. The spiritual tradition warns against pride as the root of other sins, aligning with the teaching of humility found in Proverbs 8:13.

verses.text: By mercy and truth, iniquity is atoned for, and by the fear of the LORD one turns away from evil.
verses.comment: God’s forgiveness is linked to steadfast love and truth. Turning from evil is motivated by holy reverence, much like the transformation described in Ps. 85:10.

verses.text: When a person’s ways please the LORD, He makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
verses.comment: Obedience leads to reconciliation and peace, as echoed in Psalm 23:5 with the imagery of God preparing a table before our enemies.

verses.text: Better is a little with righteousness than abundant gain with injustice.
verses.comment: Righteousness brings true wealth, a theme with echoes of Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 6:33 on seeking first God’s kingdom.

verses.text: A person plans his way, but the LORD directs his steps.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes God’s guidance over human decisions, reinforcing the need for discernment and prayer to align our ways with His will.

verses.text: A divine verdict is on the lips of a king; his mouth should not betray justice.
verses.comment: Earthly rulers are called to uphold justice, reflecting God’s authority. See the spiritual symbolism of the king as a steward in Psalm 72:1.

verses.text: Honest scales and balances belong to the LORD; all the weights in the bag are His concern.
verses.comment: God demands integrity in all dealings, echoing ancient laws that call for fairness in trade (Lev. 19:36).

verses.text: It is detestable for kings to do evil, for righteousness establishes a throne.
verses.comment: Authority is legitimized by virtue, and true leadership flows from moral character, a theme pointing forward to Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: Righteous lips are the delight of kings, and they love the one who speaks uprightly.
verses.comment: Upright speech builds trust and authority, important for all believers, underscoring Jesus’ teaching on truthfulness (Matt. 5:37).

verses.text: A king’s anger is a messenger of death, but a wise person will appease it.
verses.comment: Wisdom and tact can calm even the powerful, reflecting Christ’s teaching on peacemaking (Matt. 5:9).

verses.text: In the light of a king’s face there is life, and his favor is like a cloud of spring rain.
verses.comment: The favor of rulers brings renewal, symbolizing God’s life-giving grace and the Biblical imagery of divine blessing.

verses.text: How much better it is to get wisdom than gold, and to obtain understanding than silver!
verses.comment: Spiritual treasure exceeds material wealth, encouraging the pursuit of wisdom above riches.

verses.text: The highway of the upright turns away from evil; he guards his way who keeps his life.
verses.comment: A morally focused path protects one’s soul, reminiscent of Jesus’ exhortations to enter by the narrow gate (Matt. 7:13–14).

verses.text: Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
verses.comment: This famous warning cautions against self-exaltation, a theme expanded in many Biblical texts warning of the dangers of pride.

verses.text: It is better to be humble with the lowly than to divide spoil with the proud.
verses.comment: Humility connects us with those beloved by God. Scripture repeatedly exalts humility as a precursor to honor (Prov. 15:33).

verses.text: Whoever pays attention to instruction will find good, and blessed is the one who trusts in the LORD.
verses.comment: Obedience and trust lead to blessing, linking reverence for God’s word and living faith.

verses.text: The wise in heart will be called discerning, and gracious speech increases learning.
verses.comment: Wisdom is not only intellectual but shows itself in gentle and instructive words, fostering spiritual growth.

verses.text: Understanding is a fountain of life to those who possess it, but folly brings punishment to fools.
verses.comment: True insight is life-giving and protective, reflecting the life Jesus gives as the living water (John 4:14).

verses.text: The heart of the wise instructs his mouth and adds learning to his lips.
verses.comment: Wisdom should flow from our hearts to our words, emphasizing inner transformation leading to external fruit.

verses.text: Gracious words are like honeycomb, sweet to the soul and healing to the bones.
verses.comment: Words have real power to bring comfort and healing—literally and spiritually, echoing Christ’s gentle teaching.

verses.text: There is a way that seems right to a person, but its end leads to death.
verses.comment: Human rationale cannot replace divine truth; only God’s way is truly life-giving, connecting to Christ as the Way (John 14:6).

verses.text: A worker’s hunger works for him; his appetite drives him onward.
verses.comment: Proper desire motivates diligence; spiritual hunger can similarly motivate us to seek deeper truths.

verses.text: A worthless person plots evil, and his words are like a scorching fire.
verses.comment: Evil speech is destructive—a theme Jesus addresses regarding the power and danger of words.

verses.text: A dishonest person stirs up conflict, and a gossip separates close friends.
verses.comment: Discord and division run contrary to God’s call for unity, a deep spiritual principle reflected throughout Scripture.

verses.text: A violent person entices his neighbor and leads him down a path that is not good.
verses.comment: The influence of the wicked is a danger to the upright, warning believers to keep company with the wise.

verses.text: Whoever winks his eye plans perversity; he who purses his lips brings evil to pass.
verses.comment: Secretive gestures can reveal evil intentions, a warning to guard against hidden sin.

verses.text: Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is gained in a righteous life.
verses.comment: Long life is a blessing, especially when marked by faithfulness—a theme seen in honor for elders throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Better is a patient person than a warrior, and one who controls his temper than one who takes a city.
verses.comment: Patience and self-control are spiritual strengths, more powerful than force, echoing the virtues Christ embodied.

verses.text: The lot is cast into the lap, but every decision is from the LORD.
verses.comment: Even seemingly random outcomes are under God’s ultimate control, demonstrating His providence in all circumstances.
